title: Raven

| A raven:* can [fly](/wiki/Fly "Fly").
* has no hands.
* is an [animal](/wiki/Animal "Animal").
* is [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivore "Carnivore").
* is normally generated [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile").
* wanders randomly.
* can be seen through [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"). |                                                             |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |                                                             |
| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      | [monst.c#line1134](/wiki/Monst.c#line1134 "Monst.c")        |

A **raven**, B, is a type [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a [bird](/wiki/Bird "Bird") that is capable of [flight](/wiki/Flight "Flight"), and wanders randomly similar to the other monsters of the [bat or bird](/wiki/Bat_or_bird "Bat or bird") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class"): there is a 1⁄3 chance of a raven moving in a random direction during each of its turns.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

A raven has a bite attack and a relatively unique claw attack that deals no damage, but can [blind](/wiki/Blind "Blind") targets for d6 (more) turns - a [pair of lenses](/wiki/Pair_of_lenses "Pair of lenses") or a [helm](/wiki/Helm "Helm") with the [randomized appearance](/wiki/Randomized_appearance "Randomized appearance") of a [visored helmet](/wiki/Visored_helmet "Visored helmet") can protect against the latter attack.

A character that [polymorphs](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a raven is intrinsically [stunned](/wiki/Stun "Stun") for the duration of that form.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) Eating a floating eye [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") while in the form of a raven prints a unique message.[\[3\]](#cite_note-inyoureye-3)

[Chatting](/wiki/Chat "Chat") to a raven will cause it to reply "Nevermore!"[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [6.3 FIQHack](#FIQHack)
  - [6.4 notdNetHack](#notdNetHack)
  - [6.5 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [6.6 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly-generated ravens are always hostile.

Ravens appear among the random B that are part of the first quest [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") for [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Wizard quest](/wiki/Wizard_quest "Wizard quest").

Thirty ravens are generated on the third version of [Medusa's Island](/wiki/Medusa%27s_Island "Medusa's Island") at level creation.

Ravens generated in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") have slightly higher speed than normal, which is likely a play on the phrase "like a bat \[on its way] out of hell" even though the raven itself is not a bat (though it is part of the same monster class).[\[5\]](#cite_note-batoutofhell-5)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit 1ae2bc70](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/1ae2bc7063ebe3c3831a707efd3fc3d6fd638d26), ravens generated while the [player](/wiki/Player "Player") character is wielding a [bec de corbin](/wiki/Bec_de_corbin "Bec de corbin") are created peaceful.

## Strategy

Ravens are quite fast at 20 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") and can prove annoying to an early character, especially if you lack [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy") to detect other monsters and move safely around them - being blinded can also prevent reliably engraving [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") in a dire situation.

Characters can protect against a raven's blinding talons by actively blinding themselves a [blindfold](/wiki/Blindfold "Blindfold") or [towel](/wiki/Towel "Towel"), though they will want telepathy or [warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning") to follow the raven's erratic movement and avoid attacking peaceful monsters. A pair of [lenses](/wiki/Lenses "Lenses") or a visored helmet can also protect against the attack, though lenses can be hard to find and a visored helmet may be the randomized appearance for a [helm of opposite alignment](/wiki/Helm_of_opposite_alignment "Helm of opposite alignment"). Being polymorphed into an eyeless form will also protect against the attack.

Beyond blinding, ravens are not too threatening and can be picked off by most [ranged attacks](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack") or a [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") before they get within range.

## History

The raven first appears in [NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Raven](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raven "wikipedia:Raven")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[The Raven](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Raven "wikipedia:The Raven")***

A raven is any of several larger-bodied bird species with the genus *Corvus*. There is no singular taxonomic group within the genus, as well as no common distinction between "crows" and "ravens", which usually are assigned to the different species based on their size. Ravens are omnivorous and have a reputation alongside various other birds for seeking out a wide variety of nutrition sources: carrion, insects, berries, fruit, small animals, and even food waste. The [common raven](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/common_raven "wikipedia:common raven") (*Corvus corax*) is among the more well known members of the species, and often shows signs of unusual intelligence.

Ravens have enough of a reputation for gouging out the eyes of prey or other animals that they are the subject of at least a few proverbial sayings, up to and including its use as a metaphor in Proverbs 30:17 of The Bible. The raven also has a myriad of symbolisms and other mythic associations due to its black plumage, croaking call and carrion diet - it is both associated with loss and ill omen and considered a symbol of prophecy and insight, as well as a [psychopomp](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/psychopomp "wikipedia:psychopomp") or other similar "mediator" that bridges the worlds of the dead and the living. "The Raven", a narrative poem by American writer Edgar Allan Poe, is a popular work that incorporates many of these aspects, and is the source of the response given to *NetHack* players that chat with one in-game.

## Messages

- You peck the eyeball with delight.

  You ate the [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") of a [floating eye](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye") while polymorphed into a raven.[\[3\]](#cite_note-inyoureye-3) The message originates from [UnNetHack](#UnNetHack).

## Variants

In variants that incorporate a [grudge](/wiki/Grudge "Grudge") system, ravens will often target eye-based monsters such as the floating eye.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), ravens are the first [quest monster](/wiki/Quest_monster "Quest monster") for [Yeomen](/wiki/Yeomen "Yeomen"), and make up 96⁄175 of monsters randomly generated monsters on the [Yeoman quest](/wiki/Yeoman_quest "Yeoman quest") - two ravens are placed near the northern side of the large moat surrounding the tower upon entering the home level. Ravens also appear among the random B that are part of the first quest [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") for [Necromancers](/wiki/Necromancer "Necromancer") and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the [Necromancer quest](/wiki/Necromancer_quest "Necromancer quest").

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), ravens will attack floating eyes and [evil eyes](/wiki/Evil_eye "Evil eye"), and eating a floating eye corpse while in the form of a raven prints a unique message (which was added to vanilla *NetHack*, as shown above).

[Kicking](/wiki/Kick "Kick") a [dead tree](/wiki/Dead_tree "Dead tree") has a 1⁄5 chance of producing a hostile raven.

### FIQHack

In [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), ravens will also attack floating eyes.

### notdNetHack

In [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), ravens are likely to appear within the Dismal Swamp.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), dead trees have a 1⁄5 chance of producing a hostile raven when kicked.

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details, four ravens are generated in the village level of the [Town](/wiki/Town "Town") branch at level creation.

## Encyclopedia entry

But the raven, sitting lonely on the placid bust, spoke only  
That one word, as if his soul in that one word he did outpour.  
Nothing further then he uttered -- not a feather then he fluttered--  
Till I scarcely more than muttered, 'other friends have flown before--  
On the morrow \*he\* will leave me, as my hopes have flown before.'  
        Then the bird said, 'Nevermore.'

\[ The Raven - Edgar Allan Poe ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/monmove.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 915](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/monmove.c#L915)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [include/youprop.h in NetHack 3.6.7, line 79](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/include/youprop.h#L79)
3. ↑ [3.0](#cite_ref-inyoureye_3-0) [3.1](#cite_ref-inyoureye_3-1) [src/eat.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1692](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/eat.c#L1692)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/sounds.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 680](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/sounds.c#L680)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-batoutofhell_5-0) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1275](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L1275)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Raven

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
B raven
Difficulty 6
Attacks Bite 1d6 physical, claw 1d6 blinding
B raven
Difficulty 6
Attacks

Bite 1d6 physical, claw 1d6 blinding

Base level 4
Base experience 46
Speed 20
Base AC 6
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 2 (Quite rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 40
Nutritional value 20
Size Small
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed None

A raven:

  • can fly.
  • has no hands.
  • is an animal.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • wanders randomly.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference monst.c#line1134

A raven, B, is a type monster that appears in NetHack. It is a bird that is capable of flight, and wanders randomly similar to the other monsters of the bat or bird monster class: there is a 1⁄3 chance of a raven moving in a random direction during each of its turns.[1]

A raven has a bite attack and a relatively unique claw attack that deals no damage, but can blind targets for d6 (more) turns - a pair of lenses or a helm with the randomized appearance of a visored helmet can protect against the latter attack.

A character that polymorphs into a raven is intrinsically stunned for the duration of that form.[2] Eating a floating eye corpse or tin while in the form of a raven prints a unique message.[3]

Chatting to a raven will cause it to reply "Nevermore!"[4]

  • 2 Strategy

  • 8 References

Generation

Randomly-generated ravens are always hostile.

Ravens appear among the random B that are part of the first quest monster class for Wizards and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the Wizard quest.

Thirty ravens are generated on the third version of Medusa's Island at level creation.

Ravens generated in Gehennom have slightly higher speed than normal, which is likely a play on the phrase "like a bat [on its way] out of hell" even though the raven itself is not a bat (though it is part of the same monster class).[5]

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Per commit 1ae2bc70, ravens generated while the player character is wielding a bec de corbin are created peaceful.

Strategy

Ravens are quite fast at 20 speed and can prove annoying to an early character, especially if you lack telepathy to detect other monsters and move safely around them - being blinded can also prevent reliably engraving Elbereth in a dire situation.

Characters can protect against a raven's blinding talons by actively blinding themselves a blindfold or towel, though they will want telepathy or warning to follow the raven's erratic movement and avoid attacking peaceful monsters. A pair of lenses or a visored helmet can also protect against the attack, though lenses can be hard to find and a visored helmet may be the randomized appearance for a helm of opposite alignment. Being polymorphed into an eyeless form will also protect against the attack.

Beyond blinding, ravens are not too threatening and can be picked off by most ranged attacks or a pet before they get within range.

History

The raven first appears in NetHack 3.3.0.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Raven
Wikipedia has an article about:
The Raven

A raven is any of several larger-bodied bird species with the genus Corvus. There is no singular taxonomic group within the genus, as well as no common distinction between "crows" and "ravens", which usually are assigned to the different species based on their size. Ravens are omnivorous and have a reputation alongside various other birds for seeking out a wide variety of nutrition sources: carrion, insects, berries, fruit, small animals, and even food waste. The common raven (Corvus corax) is among the more well known members of the species, and often shows signs of unusual intelligence.

Ravens have enough of a reputation for gouging out the eyes of prey or other animals that they are the subject of at least a few proverbial sayings, up to and including its use as a metaphor in Proverbs 30:17 of The Bible. The raven also has a myriad of symbolisms and other mythic associations due to its black plumage, croaking call and carrion diet - it is both associated with loss and ill omen and considered a symbol of prophecy and insight, as well as a psychopomp or other similar "mediator" that bridges the worlds of the dead and the living. "The Raven", a narrative poem by American writer Edgar Allan Poe, is a popular work that incorporates many of these aspects, and is the source of the response given to NetHack players that chat with one in-game.

Messages

You peck the eyeball with delight.
You ate the corpse or tin of a floating eye while polymorphed into a raven.[3] The message originates from UnNetHack.

Variants

In variants that incorporate a grudge system, ravens will often target eye-based monsters such as the floating eye.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, ravens are the first quest monster for Yeomen, and make up 96⁄175 of monsters randomly generated monsters on the Yeoman quest - two ravens are placed near the northern side of the large moat surrounding the tower upon entering the home level. Ravens also appear among the random B that are part of the first quest monster class for Necromancers and make up 24⁄175 of the monsters randomly generated on the Necromancer quest.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, ravens will attack floating eyes and evil eyes, and eating a floating eye corpse while in the form of a raven prints a unique message (which was added to vanilla NetHack, as shown above).

Kicking a dead tree has a 1⁄5 chance of producing a hostile raven.

FIQHack

In FIQHack, ravens will also attack floating eyes.

notdNetHack

In notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, ravens are likely to appear within the Dismal Swamp.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, dead trees have a 1⁄5 chance of producing a hostile raven when kicked.

SlashTHEM

In SlashTHEM, in addition to SLASH'EM details, four ravens are generated in the village level of the Town branch at level creation.

Encyclopedia entry

But the raven, sitting lonely on the placid bust, spoke only
That one word, as if his soul in that one word he did outpour.
Nothing further then he uttered -- not a feather then he fluttered--
Till I scarcely more than muttered, 'other friends have flown before--
On the morrow *he* will leave me, as my hopes have flown before.'
        Then the bird said, 'Nevermore.'

[ The Raven - Edgar Allan Poe ]

A '''raven''', {{monsym|raven}}, is a type [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is a [[bird]] that is capable of [[flight]], and wanders randomly similar to the other monsters of the [[bat or bird]] [[monster class]]: there is a {{frac|3}} chance of a raven moving in a random direction during each of its turns.{{refsrc|src/monmove.c|915|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

A raven has a bite attack and a relatively unique claw attack that deals no damage, but can [[blind]] targets for d6 (more) turns - a [[pair of lenses]] or a [[helm]] with the [[randomized appearance]] of a [[visored helmet]] can protect against the latter attack.

A character that [[polymorph]]s into a raven is intrinsically [[stun]]ned for the duration of that form.{{refsrc|include/youprop.h|79|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} Eating a floating eye [[corpse]] or [[tin]] while in the form of a raven prints a unique message.<ref name="inyoureye"/>

[[Chat]]ting to a raven will cause it to reply "Nevermore!"{{refsrc|src/sounds.c|680|nethack=3.6.7}}

==Generation==
Randomly-generated ravens are always hostile.

Ravens appear among the random {{white|B}} that are part of the first quest [[monster class]] for [[Wizard]]s and make up {{frac|24|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Wizard quest]].

Thirty ravens are generated on the third version of [[Medusa's Island]] at level creation.

Ravens generated in [[Gehennom]] have slightly higher speed than normal, which is likely a play on the phrase "like a bat [on its way] out of hell" even though the raven itself is not a bat (though it is part of the same monster class).{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1275|version=NetHack 3.6.7|name=batoutofhell}}

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Per {{commit|1ae2bc7063ebe3c3831a707efd3fc3d6fd638d26}}, ravens generated while the [[player]] character is wielding a [[bec de corbin]] are created peaceful.}}

==Strategy==
Ravens are quite fast at 20 [[speed]] and can prove annoying to an early character, especially if you lack [[telepathy]] to detect other monsters and move safely around them - being blinded can also prevent reliably engraving [[Elbereth]] in a dire situation.

Characters can protect against a raven's blinding talons by actively blinding themselves a [[blindfold]] or [[towel]], though they will want telepathy or [[warning]] to follow the raven's erratic movement and avoid attacking peaceful monsters. A pair of [[lenses]] or a visored helmet can also protect against the attack, though lenses can be hard to find and a visored helmet may be the randomized appearance for a [[helm of opposite alignment]]. Being polymorphed into an eyeless form will also protect against the attack.

Beyond blinding, ravens are not too threatening and can be picked off by most [[ranged attack]]s or a [[pet]] before they get within range.

==History==
The raven first appears in [[NetHack 3.3.0]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Raven}}
{{wikipedia|The Raven}}
A raven is any of several larger-bodied bird species with the genus ''Corvus''. There is no singular taxonomic group within the genus, as well as no common distinction between "crows" and "ravens", which usually are assigned to the different species based on their size. Ravens are omnivorous and have a reputation alongside various other birds for seeking out a wide variety of nutrition sources: carrion, insects, berries, fruit, small animals, and even food waste. The [[wikipedia:common raven|common raven]] (''Corvus corax'') is among the more well known members of the species, and often shows signs of unusual intelligence.

Ravens have enough of a reputation for gouging out the eyes of prey or other animals that they are the subject of at least a few proverbial sayings, up to and including its use as a metaphor in Proverbs 30:17 of The Bible. The raven also has a myriad of symbolisms and other mythic associations due to its black plumage, croaking call and carrion diet - it is both associated with loss and ill omen and considered a symbol of prophecy and insight, as well as a [[wikipedia:psychopomp|psychopomp]] or other similar "mediator" that bridges the worlds of the dead and the living. "The Raven", a narrative poem by American writer Edgar Allan Poe, is a popular work that incorporates many of these aspects, and is the source of the response given to ''NetHack'' players that chat with one in-game.

==Messages==
{{message|You peck the eyeball with delight.|You ate the [[corpse]] or [[tin]] of a [[floating eye]] while polymorphed into a raven.{{refsrc|src/eat.c|1692|nethack=3.6.7|name="inyoureye"}} The message originates from [[#UnNetHack|UnNetHack]].}}

==Variants==
In variants that incorporate a [[grudge]] system, ravens will often target eye-based monsters such as the floating eye.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], ravens are the first [[quest monster]] for [[Yeomen]], and make up {{frac|96|175}} of monsters randomly generated monsters on the [[Yeoman quest]] - two ravens are placed near the northern side of the large moat surrounding the tower upon entering the home level. Ravens also appear among the random {{white|B}} that are part of the first quest [[monster class]] for [[Necromancer]]s and make up {{frac|24|175}} of the monsters randomly generated on the [[Necromancer quest]].

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], ravens will attack floating eyes and [[evil eye]]s, and eating a floating eye corpse while in the form of a raven prints a unique message (which was added to vanilla ''NetHack'', as shown above).

[[Kick]]ing a [[dead tree]] has a {{frac|5}} chance of producing a hostile raven.

===FIQHack===
In [[FIQHack]], ravens will also attack floating eyes.

===notdNetHack===
In [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], ravens are likely to appear within the Dismal Swamp.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], dead trees have a {{frac|5}} chance of producing a hostile raven when kicked.

===SlashTHEM===
In [[SlashTHEM]], in addition to SLASH'EM details, four ravens are generated in the village level of the [[Town]] branch at level creation.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
But the raven, sitting lonely on the placid bust, spoke only
That one word, as if his soul in that one word he did outpour.
Nothing further then he uttered -- not a feather then he fluttered--
Till I scarcely more than muttered, 'other friends have flown before--
On the morrow *he* will leave me, as my hopes have flown before.'
        Then the bird said, 'Nevermore.'
|[ The Raven - Edgar Allan Poe ]
}}
